The Trump Administration and Republicans in Congress would happily see these life-saving measures denied to millions of Americans. That is unacceptable! I will keep fighting for the health care of ALL Nevadans.

The repeal of the ACA would not only mean that 371,000 of our fellow Nevadans would lose coverage this year, but Nevadans with private health coverage would also lose guaranteed access to free preventative care like immunizations and cancer screenings.

But now, 54 years later, the expansion of health care access brought about by these programs is back in the crosshairs of the Trump Administration as it attempts to use the courts to undermine health care access and repeal the #ACA.
Every year, #Medicaid provides health care coverage to 65 million children and adults, including 2.9 million Nevadans. Medicare provides insurance to half a million of Nevada’s seniors.
Today marks the 54th anniversary of #Medicare and #Medicaid, two landmark programs that set the groundwork for expanding health care access. pic.twitter.com/FcIyTgKvlW

I am taking part in this taskforce for my constituents in Nevada. Undercounting urban communities like Las Vegas can result in an unfair distribution of congressional seats and deny communities of color, specifically Black communities, access to representation in #Congress.

In 2010, the African American census undercount was roughly 800,000. I will work with my colleagues until and beyond the April 2020 census count to increase participation and make sure our communities are given the resources and funding they deserve.

The Constitution declares that we must count all persons in this country. There have been actions from this Administration that have been specifically coordinated to discourage and frighten people away from participating in the 2020 census, and now we are fighting back.

Today, I'm proud to announce with my @TheBlackCaucus colleagues, the creation of our Census 2020 Taskforce, to ensure a fair and accurate count of all people in the United States. pic.twitter.com/nrkIU38jJ1

Today, I stood in support of the Middle-Class Health Benefits Tax Repeal Act, which would eliminate a 40 percent tax on high-premium employer-sponsored health care coverage, the so-called "Cadillac Tax" to #ProtectOurCare: pic.twitter.com/b4gG3Qldg7

I’m going to the floor now to push for the repeal of the excise tax on health plans affecting 1.3 million in Nevada so we can #ProtectOurCare. 

Watch here:  https://live.house.gov/

I urge all of my colleagues today to stand with America’s working men and women and vote in favor of abolishing this tax. Now is the time to decide which side you’re on: the side of protecting the health of our people, or the side that would deny Americans #AffordableCare.

To avoid the Cadillac Tax, employers will in all likelihood reduce the value of their plans and reduce benefits and even increase their workers’ share of the cost. This would result in increases in out-of-pocket costs for 177 million workers across the country.
Half said costs had forced them to delay a doctor’s appointment, not fill a prescription or postpone a surgery or procedure in the previous year.

One in six Americans who get insurance through their jobs say they’ve had to make ‘difficult sacrifices’ to pay for healthcare in the last year, including cutting back on food, moving in with friends or family, or taking extra jobs.

For many working families, necessary medical treatment remains tragically unaffordable due to exorbitant out of pocket costs and deductibles. If this tax isn’t repealed, this crisis of affordability for medical care will only worsen.

Today, we'll be headed to the House floor to debate the Middle Class Health Benefits Repeal Act—also known as a repeal of the so-called Cadillac Tax, a 40-percent tax on high premium employer-sponsored health care coverage. #AffordableCare pic.twitter.com/gvoiMQTymA

It’s in the president’s best interest to keep us distracted, rather than letting my colleagues & I work to fight his prejudiced policies. I look forward to working #ForThePeople: lowering healthcare costs, reigning in prescription drug prices, & raising wages of Nevada families.

Instead, the House was forced to spend the day condemning the president’s racist remarks, restoring @SpeakerPelosi's privilege to speak and changing our rules so we could take action to hold President Trump accountable.

I believe one job should be enough: Enough to provide for you and your family. Enough to put a roof over your head. Enough to afford the co-pays and prescriptions you need to stay well. Enough to put food on your table. Enough set your children up for success. #RaiseTheWage

There's no place in America where a full-time worker making $7.25 an hour can support their family and afford basic needs. That is unacceptable. #RaisetheWage would lift 1.3 million Americans, including 600,000 children out of poverty. It’s not a partisan issue—it’s a human one.

A pay increase will benefit 127,500 workers in my district. Specifically, it will raise wages for 18,800 Black workers—more than any other District in Nevada. Since 2000, the wage gap between black and white workers has grown significantly. #RaiseTheWage is a step to fix this.

#RaiseTheWage would greatly benefit these Black working families, who are overrepresented among low-wage workers and are less likely to live in states that have passed a minimum wage that is higher than the current federal minimum.

Last night, I stood with @StaceyPlaskett and the @TheBlackCaucus to discuss #RaisetheWage, and the impact that would have not only on the workforce at large, but for Black working families across the U.S. We’re working #ForThePeople to give 27 million Americans a raise. pic.twitter.com/5HgxeSBXN6

Sadly, the U.S. is the only country in the developed world with an increasing infant mortality rate.
Black women are nearly 4 times more likely than white women—and more than twice as likely as women of other races—to die from preventable, pregnancy-related complications.

As Representative of District 4 of Nevada, which is home to the National Nuclear Security Site, I vow to investigate the past and current conduct of the DOE and hold them accountable for their dismissal of the law and blatant disregard for the safety of Nevadans.

To add insult to injury the DOE reluctantly admitted that the waste shipped to Nevada was incorrectly labelled as low-level radioactive waste, when it was in fact mixed low-level radioactive waste. The implications could be significant for both our environment and public health.

Today we found out that, against the will and consent of Nevadans, the Department of Energy has been covertly shipping dangerous radioactive waste into our state. Secretary Perry has repeatedly disrespected the people of Nevada and eroded the public trust.

Secretary Perry has repeatedly disrespected the people of Nevada. He must resign immediately. https://horsford.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-horsford-calls-resignation-secretary-rick-perry-wake-unapproved …

Earthquakes are dangerous enough—adding the possibility of a nuclear waste spill is not a risk I am willing to take. https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/earthquakes-rattle-yucca-mountain-debate-1707159/ …
I'm fighting every day in Congress for people like Joe--for more than half of all Nevadans who could lose their health care coverage if the #ACA is eliminated in #TexasvUS. #ProtectOurCare

Joe’s tracheotomy hole never healed, and he experienced a complication that impacted his ability to breathe and kept him from going to work. In 2014, he was notified that his employee-sponsored health care would end, and he could not afford a COBRA plan on his disability payment.

One of those Nevadans is Joe Merlino, who lives in North Las Vegas. Joe was diagnosed with cancer in 2011: chondrosarcoma of the larynx. In 2013, Joe underwent a 12-hour surgery to remove much of the tumor. He awoke with a tracheotomy which he would have in for months.

In my district, 371,000 Nevadans would lose coverage if the ACA were repealed. 51% of Nevadans live with a pre-existing condition. Because of the #ACA, insurance companies can no longer deny coverage or charge more because of a pre-existing condition.
I'm proud to have voted to let the House step in to protect the #AffordableCareAct and the millions of Americans who depend on it. #ProtectOurCare

Today, I stood with @SpeakerPelosi, @SenSchumer and my colleagues in Congress to tell the Trump administration that we won't let them strip away health care for the 130 million Americans and 1.2 million Nevadans living with pre-existing conditions. #ProtectOurCare

Nevada was the first state to expand Medicaid and implement insurance exchanges. These actions have cut our state’s uninsured rate in half. I will not allow those Nevadans who now have access to affordable health care to go backward in time. #ProtectOurCare
My colleagues and I are working every day to protect Nevadans health care. Republicans would like to see those protections taken away. Which team is #ForThePeople?

On my very first day in Congress, I voted to allow the House of Representatives to intervene in this case to defend the #AffordableCareAct—including Nevada’s Medicaid expansion, and protections for Nevadans with pre-existing conditions. #ProtectOurCare

More than 130 million Americans and 1.2 million Nevadans live with a pre-existing condition. If the #TexasVUS lawsuit succeeds, they’ll be once again left at the mercy of insurance companies who’ve already proved willing to run up bills for families nationwide. #ProtectOurCare

“The Trump Administration has spent more than two years trying to take health coverage away from 100 million Americans and 1.2 million people in my home state of Nevada ... As #civilrights and #Labor activist A. Philip Randolph said, “If someone tried to deprive you of your rights, you've got to resist it.” The #LaborRelationsAct has allowed workers to resist for 85 years and will continue to do so for many more.

Before I started working for Nevadans in #Congress, I worked alongside @culinary226 at the Culinary Training Academy to prepare Nevadans to enter the workforce. I've seen the support that #unions offer their members and the amazing things that can be done when workers unite.

Nevada is home to 191,000 union members, with another 25,000 covered by union contracts. Unions have secured job safety laws, overtime pay, Medicare and Social Security, civil rights protections, fair treatment for women and #LGBTQ workers.

Today is the anniversary of the National #LaborRelationsAct, passed in 1934 to protect workers and their right to unionize. Every day, I use my role as your Congressman to champion for working families and uphold the standards of the #NLRA.

55 years on from the #CivilRightsAct, it is my job, and the job of my peers in #Congress, to champion for the rights of those who remain the target of systemic discrimination and fight every day to change the injustices that hold them down.

The passing of the #CivilRightsAct did not rid our country of prejudice or racism. We must continue the work every day to look our differences in the face and stand up to those who espouse hatred and bigotry.

In addressing the nation about the #civilrightsact, President Johnson declared that “our generation of Americans has been called on to continue the unending search for justice within our own borders." That rings as true today as it did in 1964.
#OTD, 55 years ago, the Civil Rights Act was enacted, outlawing discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex or national origin.

#OTD in 1971, the 26th Amendment was ratified, lowering the voting age to 18. Young voters have the power to shape the future of our country. 

For more info on voting: 

 https://vote.gov/
